thread.title: Chance for northern lights again Thursday night
thread.title_full: Chance for northern lights again Thursday night

author: Paul Huttner
title: Chance for northern lights again Thursday night
text:
Chance for northern lights again Thursday night
Severe geomagnetic storm blasting Earth with energy
Go Deeper.
Create an account or log in to save stories.
Like this?
Thanks for liking this story! We have added it to a list of your favorite stories.
You may want to take a peek at the sky after dark Thursday night.
A severe geomagnetic storm is pummeling Earth. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Space Weather Prediction Center has issued a severe geomagnetic storm alert.
The K index peaks at 9 and is running at 8.3 as of late Thursday afternoon.
If the storm continues after dark it could be a great aurora show above Minnesota. Auroras are fickle to forecast because the magnetosphere must interact with inbound solar energy in the right way to produce auroras.
Turn Up Your Support
MPR News helps you turn down the noise and build shared understanding. Turn up your support for this public resource and keep trusted journalism accessible to all.
As of this post, auroras are already occurring in much of Europe after dark. So keep an eye out anytime after dark in Minnesota. Best viewing is always away from city lights with a good view of the northern sky.
You may also be able to catch a glimpse of the comet C/2023 A3 Tsuchinshan-ATLAS low in the western sky just after sunset.
Good luck!
Cooler days ahead
A series of cool fronts will bring freezing temperatures to most of Minnesota by Monday morning.
Expect widespread frost and freezes early next week!
